abstracts.cdata!:
The project on the whole is rated fully
            satisfactory. These are key lessons learned: 1) Fund
            non-structural measures that establish the capacity to
            manage future emergencies. 2) Use simple and easy
            investments and a flexible project design; ensure
            participation of interested provinces; maintain competent
            local executing units; enable flexibility to shift funds
            among eligible provinces; and prepare a well-formulated but
            simple project operation's manual. 3) The institutional
            set-up of the central and provincial sub-units coordinating
            emergencies was crucial to implementing and sustaining
            communication and coordination. 4) Emergency operations with
            a housing component to voluntary resettlement should help
            define land-use regulations. 5) To restrict development in
            floodplains and preserve the ecosystem, use financial
            incentives, practice effective land use and management, and
            sound governmental policies and programs. 6) Simplify
            procurement procedures and ensure they are properly used by
            auditing projects semi-annually. 7) Review proposed
            sub-projects for their technological and environmental
            aptness. 8) The use of a structured implementation framework
            with a very capable project executing unit was key. 9)
            Strong Bank and borrower supervision is required. 10)
            Beneficiary participation is essential. 11) In order for an
            emergency loan to be implemented quickly, overall Bank
            financing of an emergency operation should be a minimum of
            60 to 70 percent.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to
            help finance flood reconstruction needs in the seven
            afflicted provinces and provide a sound institutional
            framework for coordination and implementation of the overall
            government rehabilitation program.  The specific project
            activities, designed to restore normal economic activity in
            the areas affected, include assisting in the rehabilitation
            of essential transport infrastructure, social
            infrastructure, and flood control works.  The project will
            finance rehabilitation investments in key infrastructure and
            equipment for:  (a) transport and energy; (b) emergency
            flood control works; (c) housing; (d) education and health
            facilities; (e) water supply and drainage; (f) additional
            requirements to be determined after final damage assessment;
            (g) technical assistance to strengthen the institutions
            involved in project implementation; and (h) flood
            forecasting and prevention of future disasters, including
            technical assistance.
